head.title: Accident Case Dropped Against O'Rourke Son

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New York

hedline.hl1: Accident Case Dropped Against O'Rourke Son

body.head.byline: Special to the New York Times

block.p: LEAD: Drunken-driving charges against Andrew P. O'Rourke Jr., the 31-year-old son of the Westchester County Eexecutive, were dismissed here today by Town Justice Robert Troup, who decided there was insufficient evidence.

LEAD: Drunken-driving charges against Andrew P. O'Rourke Jr., the 31-year-old son of the Westchester County Eexecutive, were dismissed here today by Town Justice Robert Troup, who decided there was insufficient evidence.

Drunken-driving charges against Andrew P. O'Rourke Jr., the 31-year-old son of the Westchester County Eexecutive, were dismissed here today by Town Justice Robert Troup, who decided there was insufficient evidence.

State Trooper William Kelly testified that he found the defendant ''confused and incoherent'' at 9:30 P.M. last March 17 when he called at Mr. O'Rourke's home in Ossining, but said no tests for alcohol use had been taken at 7:30 P.M., the time of the accident.

Mr. O'Rourke, a newscaster for a Westchester radio station, had stopped after his car struck that of Arthur Bergquist of Ossining, a computer programmer. Mr. O'Rourke then left, saying he was going to get help for possible injuries to a companion in the car.

Justice Troup said there was not enough evidence to show that a crime had been committed. Mr. O'Rourke had a previous conviction for driving while intoxicated in 1980, which meant that he would have faced as much as four years in prison if convicted a second time within 10 years.
